headline: Nets 98, Blazers 96
summary: Harris's 25 points and clutch three led the way.

headline: Level of Medical Care Depends on Situation
summary: The question about quality of medical care was a "red herring."

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Nov. 29, 2010

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Nov. 29, 2010

headline: School Stampede in Western China
summary: A mad rush to the playground turned into a stampede that left dozens of elementary school children injured in western China on Monday, state media and officials said.

headline: Once Tossed Aside, a Homecoming for Sony's E-Reader
summary: Sony Corp.'s digital e-book reader, which will go on sale in Japan on Dec. 10, is the rare example of a consumer product being reintroduced in Japan after an initial flop at home and then finding success abroad.

headline: Rangers Are Interested in Pettite
summary: Andy Pettitte has yet to announce whether he will pitch next season, but if he does, Texas could be an intriguing option.

headline: Mayor Hasn't Been Meek About School Control
summary: Mayor Michael Bloomberg declared Monday there won't be any power sharing at the helm of New York City's school system, echoing his stance eight years ago when he brokered a deal with state lawmakers to create a panel to replace the defunct Board of Education.

headline: Server Sales Soar
summary: Sales of server systems jumped 15% in the third quarter, according to research firm Gartner, a sign that large technology companies and other businesses are again spending big on tech projects.

headline: Gillard Pledges to Push Climate Change
summary: Australian Prime Minister Julia Gillard vowed to press ahead with economy-shaping initiatives on climate policy and health care in 2011 despite her center-left Labor Party's fragile grip on power.

headline: Porsche Swings to Profit
summary: Porsche Automobil Holding said it swung to a $205.3 million net profit in the first three months of its fiscal year after suffering a €431 million loss a year earlier.

headline: Partying In Palm Beach
summary: The Paradise Fund party brought out a surprisingly young crowd, one that normally, around this time of year, takes over local watering holes like E.R. Bradley's, Michael R. McCarty's and Cucina dell'Arte.

headline: Bank of Ireland to Raise Funds
summary: The Bank of Ireland and Irish Life & Permanent Group are launching capital-raising drives to meet the terms of the country's multibillion-euro bailout. Separately, Central Bank of Ireland Gov. Patrick Honohan said there is no indication that Irish banks have further big hidden losses on their books.

headline: Shanda Profit Falls 77%
summary: Shanda Interactive's third-quarter profit slid 77% as expenses jumped, while its Shanda Games arm saw profit decline 21% on lower revenue and margins.

headline: BA, Iberia Shareholders Back Merger
summary: British Airways shareholders voted overwhelmingly in favor of the company's merger with Spain's Iberia, the final step before the carriers become International Consolidated Airlines Group in the new year.

headline: Ireland Bailout Fails to Calm Investors
summary: The Irish rescue package failed to soothe market worries that sovereign-debt problems might spread, pushing the euro lower and raising yields on the debt of fiscally weaker euro-zone countries.

headline: Wikileaks: Quotes from Leaked U.S. Cables
summary: The publication of a quarter-million sensitive diplomatic cables Sunday exposed years of U.S. foreign-policy maneuvering that could prove embarrassing to the U.S. and its allies, especially in the Islamic world. Read quotes from some of the leaked documents.

headline: East Village Soba
summary: Bento boxes and donburi specials dot the menu at Sobakoh in the East Village. But the soba, which is handmade using organic buckwheat flour, is the main draw.

headline: Leaks Show Arabs Leaders Hawkish on Iran
summary: Middle Eastern governments were silent about leaked U.S. intelligence made available over the weekend by WikiLeaks, which disclosed more-hawkish views by Arab leaders about Iran than they generally have voiced publicly, as well as some withering and indelicate comments about allied regional leaders themselves.

headline: Cellulosic Ethanol Target Is Lowered
summary: The Obama administration conceded that cellulosic ethanol producers won't come close to hitting a congressional target to deliver 250 million gallons of fuel next year made from grasses and other vegetation not used for food.

headline: Haiti Battles Through Election
summary: A day after Haiti's chaotic presidential election, Haitians were left to wonder on Monday not only who might have won the contest, but whether the vote would count at all

headline: New Securities Issues
summary: The following were among recent offerings and pricings in U.S. and non-U.S. capital markets, with terms and syndicate manager, based on information provided by Dow Jones Newswires and Factiva.

headline: 'Crimes Were Committed,' U.S. Says
summary: Holder said the U.S. was looking to prosecute those responsible for the leak of diplomatic cables, as WikiLeaks said it would release more secret cables in coming days.

headline: 'Santa Claus Rally' at Top of Investors' Wish List
summary: The U.S. stock market's best-performing month on a historic basis is only days away, but investors would be wise to tread cautiously as December approaches.

headline: GM's Benign Outlook, and Uncle Sam's Woe
summary: The options market envisions a benign, if staid, future for GM stock. It also has a warning for the government: Don't expect to recoup your full GM investment.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's pictures, a worker bends steel in Pakistan, Haitians recover from turbulent elections, a man hauls a trash find in Nicaragua.

headline: Program Trading
summary: Program trading in the week ended Nov. 19 amounted to 30.0% of New York Stock Exchange average daily volume of 2.24 billion shares, or 674.0 million program shares traded per day. This included program trading associated with the Nov. 19 monthly expiration of stock-index options and futures.

headline: New Jersey County Trash Authority Is Expected to Avoid Default
summary: A New Jersey trash authority that runs a landfill and waste-to-energy facility is expected to avert default on a large debt payment due Wednesday, thanks to unprecedented action from a state board.

headline: UBS Wealth Unit Names Chief Investment Strategist
summary: UBS Wealth Management Americas named Mike Ryan its chief investment strategist.

headline: Swap Prices Highlight EU Worries
summary: A sharp rise in the cost of insuring peripheral European sovereign bonds from default on Monday underscored the disappointment many market participants feel about the size and terms of the Irish bailout.

headline: Fiat to Supply Commercial Vehicles to Opel
summary: Fiat on Monday announced a deal to supply a range of light commercial vehicles to Adam Opel, the German unit of U.S. car maker General Motors Co. that Fiat tried to take over in 2009.

headline: Medicare Cuts for Doctors Delayed
summary: Congress agreed to delay cuts in Medicare payments to physicians until Jan. 1. The temporary delay would avoid a 25% cut in the payments that otherwise would have taken effect next month.

headline: Analysts See No Euro Reprieve
summary: The bailout package for Ireland hasn't stopped the euro's slide, with the crisis-plagued common currency likely to keep slumping in December.

headline: Crude Climbs Near $86 a Barrel
summary: Investors brushed off concerns about the euro zone, lower stock markets and a higher dollar.

headline: Gold Futures Edge Up
summary: Worries about European sovereign debt supported prices, but a move into the dollar capped gains in the metal.

headline: Investors See Less ValueIn Asset-Backed Bonds
summary: The asset-backed securities market, already hit by shrinking supply as consumers have reined in spending, is facing shrinking demand as investors migrate to other markets in a quest for greater returns.

headline: Kremlin Plays Down 'Batman' Comments
summary: Russian officials downplayed the release of confidential U.S. diplomatic documents that portray Prime Minister Putin as the dominant ruler in a "virtual mafia state" and President Medvedev as "Robin to Putin's Batman."

headline: European Stocks End Lower on Contagion Fears
summary: European stock markets fell, unable to hold on to early gains as the initial enthusiasm over Ireland's rescue package faded and the focus shifted to other indebted "peripheral" euro-zone nations, such as Spain and Portugal.

headline: Tam's Brazil Ticket Sales Halted After Delays
summary: Brazil's civil aviation regulator Monday suspended sales of Tam SA tickets for domestic flights departing this week after the company reported delays above the industry average.

headline: FDA Questions Using Avodart to Cut Prostate Cancer Risk
summary: The FDA questioned the clinical benefit of using GlaxoSmithKline's Avodart to cut the risk of prostate cancer.

headline: Merck Halts Study of Once-Daily HIV Drug
summary: Merck will end a study of HIV drug Isentress after initial results showed a once-daily dosage wasn't as effective as the standard twice-daily regimen.

headline: China Huaneng Sets Power Deal
summary: China Huaneng agreed to buy India-based GMR Group's 50% stake in U.S.-based power-generation company InterGen for $1.23 billion, expanding Chinese investment in overseas energy assets.

headline: Europe Falls; Five-Month High for Nikkei
summary: European stock markets stumbled as investors shifted their attention to the debts of Spain and Portugal, but stocks in Japan rose to the highest levels in five months.

headline: Rio Police Fight Slum Violence
summary: Backed by military hardware and hundreds of soldiers, Rio de Janeiro police appeared to get the upper hand in a deadly weeklong battle against heavily-armed gangs that rule many of the city's sprawling hillside shantytowns.

headline: iShares MSCI Emerging Markets, JPMorgan Chase: Money Flow Leaders (EEM, JPM)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Graft Fighter Alleges Pakistan Threat
summary: Corruption watchdog Transparency International says it is facing intimidation in Pakistan because of its agreement with the U.S. to monitor increased aid flows to the country.

headline: Investors Turn Dim on Currencies of Poland, Hungary
summary: The Polish zloty hit a four-month low against the euro, while the Hungarian forint also weakened as financial markets continued to fret about contagion to other fiscally weak euro-zone members, namely Portugal and Spain.

headline: Cairn-Vedanta Deal Is Delayed
summary: India's government said it doesn't expect to decide until February whether to allow Cairn Energy to sell a majority stake in its Indian assets to Vedanta—two months later than previously expected.

headline: National Bank of Greece's Profit Falls 74%
summary: National Bank of Greece, Greece's largest lender by assets, said its nine-month net profit fell 74% on sharply higher provisions for bad loans, as expected. NBG's nine-month net interest income rose 7% to €3.11 billion.

headline: Singapore's Global Logistics Profit Soars
summary: Global Logistic Properties' second-quarter net profit nearly doubled because of increased contributions from its China business and the strengthening of the Japanese yen against the U.S. dollar.

headline: EU Forecasts Choppy Recovery
summary: The European Commission said it expects weak global markets and government deficit cuts across the European Union to drive a "gradual and rather uneven" recovery across the bloc's 27 member states.

headline: New Zealand Mining Reviewed
summary: Safety at all New Zealand's underground coal mines will be scrutinized as part of a far-reaching review following an accident that left 29 miners presumed dead.

headline: U.K. Cuts Growth Forecast
summary: The U.K.'s independent Office for Budget Responsibility cut its official growth forecast slightly for 2011 and 2012 but kept its borrowing estimates relatively unchanged.

headline: TCU to Bolt Mountain West for Big East
summary: In another major shift to the college-sports landscape, TCU is moving from the Mountain West to the Big East after the 2011-12 academic year.

headline: 82 Sites Seized in U.S. Piracy Crackdown
summary: Federal authorities on Monday said they seized 82 Internet websites allegedly used to distribute counterfeit products as part of a crackdown on the sale of counterfeit and pirated products.

headline: High Court Allows Full Damages for Music Theft
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court refused Monday to consider whether a Texas woman who was sued for downloading music illegally can argue that she was too young and naive to know she was violating copyright laws.

headline: Tiffany Stymied on eBay Suit
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court refused to consider a Tiffany lawsuit against eBay over the sale of counterfeit jewelry on the auction website. Two lower courts sided with eBay, saying the auctioneer couldn't be held liable.

headline: South Koreans Evaluate Damage
summary: On Sunday, South Korea and the U.S. began a joint naval exercise as a show of force. Meanwhile, on Yeonpyeong Island, most of the 1,400 civilian residents are gone..

headline: Thanksgiving Kitchens
summary: During Thanksgiving week, N.Y. House of the Day highlighted homes with remarkable kitchens from New Canaan to New York City. In which kitchen would you have liked to prepare your turkey?

headline: The Worldwide World Cup Mystery
summary: A lack of transparency makes this week's recipients of the 2018 and 2022 World Cups anyone's guess.

headline: Ready, Set, Shop!
summary: U.S. retailers ushered in the traditional kickoff of the country's holiday shopping season Friday with expanded hours, deep discounts and online deals. Bargain-hungry shoppers gave them a strong turnout.

headline: Shoppers Boost Tokyo; Tension Troubles Seoul
summary: Asian stock market indexes ended mixed, with Tokyo's Nikkei Stock Average hitting a five-month closing high as the outlook for exporters brightened, while South Korean stocks were pressured by tensions on the peninsula.

headline: Colorful Colonial
summary: Each room of this roughly 6,350-square-foot colonial home in Short Hills, N.J., is accented with different colors to match the owner's upbeat personality.

headline: Pumpkin House
summary: The Pumpkin House of Washington Heights, one of the most unusual residences in Manhattan, has gone on the market for $3.9 million.

headline: Cord-Cutting Avoids Biggest Cities
summary: For the first time since the dawn of cable TV, the number of U.S. households paying for TV subscriptions is falling, marking a potential turning point in the TV business.

headline: Egypt Reins in Religious Candidate
summary: Egypt, a U.S. ally and the recipient of billions of dollars worth of U.S. aid and military support, is cracking down on the Muslim Brotherhood ahead of parliamentary elections.

headline: In Surprise, Euro-Zone Inflation Climbs
summary: Consumer prices in the 16 countries that use the euro rose at the fastest rate in two years during October.

headline: EU: Spain Faces Long Road to Recovery
summary: The Spanish economy has yet to embark on a robust recovery path, although it stabilized this year after a deep recession in 2008 and 2009, the European Commission said.

headline: Competition Emerges for Seoul's Stake in Woori
summary: Competition for Woori's regional units is likely to bolster Seoul's efforts to maximize recovery of public funds injected into the holding company with the sale of its 57% stake.

headline: Orix Seeks Overseas Acquisitions
summary: Orix is seeking a foreign acquisition that could propel its fee-based business, including asset management, as a growth driver, Yoshihiko Miyauchi, chairman and chief executive officer said.

headline: Short-Term Yields Rise in Japan
summary: The 10-year Japanese government-bond yield fell Monday on bargain hunting, but short-dated debt yields rose on a weaker yen and the view among some investors that the Bank of Japan isn't doing enough to support the sector.

headline: Imagining Life With No BCS
summary: With college presidents not budging on the playoff question, would college football really be better off with any other alternative?

headline: Deutsche Bank Prepares Postbank Consolidation
summary: Deutsche Bank said Deutsche Postbank shareholders had tendered about 22% of their shares in a move that prepares Deutsche Bank to consolidate the retail bank onto its balance sheet this year.

headline: Indian Truckers Threaten Strike
summary: Truckers in India are planning to strike indefinitely starting Sunday to protest against higher taxes on road transportation, unleashing fears that this will lead to a spike in food-price inflation.

headline: Tencent Seeks Third-Party Contributions
summary: Tencent Holdings plans to speed up the pace at which it opens some platforms to partners and third-party developers, giving the public a rare glimpse into the Chinese Internet giant's strategy.

headline: India Shares End Higher After Days of Losses
summary: Short-covering helped Indian shares end higher Monday, snapping a four-day losing streak triggered by an alleged bribery scandal.

headline: Euro-Zone Confidence Maintains Rise
summary: Consumers and businesses across much of the euro zone continued to grow more confident about their prospects in November, despite the loss of faith among bond investors that culminated when Ireland became the euro-zone's second nation to need external financial help.

summary: The U.S. and South Korea began a major naval exercise designed to deter North Korea, after the communist state warned of "unpredictable consequences" if the drill goes ahead.

headline: U.K. Mortgage Lending, Consumer Credit Rise
summary: U.K. consumers' appetite for debt, and their ability to secure it, picked up in October, data from the Bank of England showed.

headline: At Aer Lingus, Flying Through Storm
summary: Buffeted by an ailing economy and a major shareholder, Aer Lingus's CEO says constant change is key to survival

headline: Angst Over Pro-Pyongyang Schools in Japan
summary: Tokyo has threatened to cut off support for North Korean schools in Japan, thrusting the pro-Pyongyang ethnic Korean community there in the spotlight.

headline: Satyam Sees U.S. Revenue Rising

headline: Larsen Aims to Cash in on India Nuclear Boom
summary: Larsen & Toubro aims to attract up to $2 billion of orders a year for nuclear power equipment from India's ambitious plans to increase atomic energy capacity 15-fold over 20 years.

headline: China Moves to Cool Korean Tensions
summary: China called for emergency discussions among delegates to the six-party talks as the U.S. and South Korea started a naval drill that has prompted dire warnings of reprisals from North Korea.

summary: Indian athletes have fared well by recording their best ever medal haul in the just concluded Asian Games held in Guangzhou, China and also at the Commonwealth Games held in New Delhi. Some snapshots.

headline: Working to Make Every Day Cyber Monday
summary: This holiday season, some retailers may be content to see shoppers stay home. Online shopping has gained steam as retailers beef up Web offerings.

summary: For state-run Petrobras, the Gulf spill is no cause for pulling back

headline: Autodesk Broadens Its Reach
summary: Software maker Autodesk is introducing consumer products as the company seeks to expand the market for its design software beyond professionals.

headline: Aer Lingus Defies Irish Turmoil
summary: Aer Lingus Chief Executive Christoph Mueller is trying to continue a turnaround in the face of Ireland's mounting economic troubles.

headline: Egypt's Ruling Party Seen Winning Big
summary: Egypt's largest opposition party, the Muslim Brotherhood, appeared headed for a drubbing in parliamentary elections marred by scattered violence, widespread fraud allegations and a sweeping government clampdown on dissent.

headline: EU Bailout Plan Eases Uncertainty, If Not Pain
summary: European finance ministers hope establishing ground rules for bailouts of euro-zone governments after July 2013 will help calm financial markets spooked by the prospect of defaults in Europe's sovereign bond markets.

headline: Forget Research: Just Count Your Blessings
summary: Do we need expensive research studies, doctors and worksheets to teach our children to show gratitude or to prove its value?

headline: Tablets Seen Sapping PC Demand
summary: Gartner cut its global personal-computer shipments forecast for 2010 and 2011 as consumers rein in spending and interest grows in tablet devices such as Apple's iPad.

summary: After signing up Kraft Foods in 1998 to help sell Starbucks-branded products outside its cafes, the coffee giant is trying to wrest back control of the venture.

headline: Obama, McConnell Fail to Kindle Bond
summary: The question of what legislation advances in the next two years could depend in large measure on whether and how Sen. McConnell and President Obama choose to work together.

headline: From Old Garage to New Condos
summary: With luxurious floor-to-ceiling windows and views of bluestone Hicks Street backyards and Brooklyn Heights chimneys, the feel of Love Lane Mews is Gordon Gekko-meets-Mary Poppins.

headline: Cleaning Out Indian Stock Portfolios
summary: It is becoming something of a ritual in India: A cleansing, but not of one's spirit. Rather this scrubbing is of stock portfolios.

headline: Federer and Nadal Rekindle a Rivalry
summary: Roger Federer tops Rafael Nadal in the ATP World Tour Finals in a match that reinvigorated a clash that recently had become one-sided. And pro surfer Kelly Slater unveils technology to build artificial wave pools.

headline: Pajama Party: New Congress Members Plan to Sleep Over
summary: In the ultimate I'm-not-a-professional-politician statement, 15% of the incoming lawmakers plan to bed down in their congressional offices.

headline: Stars in Line for Gains in Treasurys
summary: Treasurys have room to rally this week with the market set to see a slew of Federal Reserve purchases, month-end buying and lingering concerns about the fiscal health of several euro-zone nations.

headline: Editor's Note
summary: What if we're going about it all wrong? Ted Nordhaus and Michael Shellenberger argue that's exactly what's happening in the global effort to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions.

headline: BofA Stock Declines on WikiLeaks Anticipation
summary: Bank of America stock dropped more than 3% on speculation that website WikiLeaks would soon release internal documents.

headline: Playing the Nuclear Card
summary: As China looks to wean itself off coal, CLP Holdings—a Hong Kong utility that is the biggest foreign player in mainland China's power sector—sees a major opportunity.

headline: For Cyber Shoppers, Gadgets Look Hot
summary: The holiday shopping season, which starts online Cyber Monday, promises to be very good for smartphones and Apple's gadgets.

summary: In "Once Before Time," Martin Bojowald proposes a model for the universe and its origins—an alternative to the "string theory" that has dominated the thinking of physicists in recent years.

summary: The Bowery mural wall, which had been curated by Deitch Projects until that gallery closed in June, is now under the stewardship of the Hole gallery and real-estate developer Tony Goldman.

summary: I fear we are—as a country and world—close to the point where no one will listen or care about the rule of law.

headline: IPOs to Make a Final Lunge
summary: Bankers are likely to try to cram as many new stock listings as possible into the few remaining weeks of 2010.

headline: Tokyo Is Boosted By Retail Hopes
summary: Asian stock markets were mixed in early trading, with Tokyo exporters cheered by indications of strong retail sales over the Black Friday weekend.

headline: Times Square Loo Tunes
summary: Ralph Gardner visits the Charmin "Enjoy the Go" restrooms on 42nd Street  and admires the company's courage to celebrate the bathroom break.

headline: Levees Fall Off Face of Map
summary: The levee that has protected Granite City, Ill. for nearly six decades is 52 feet high and so wide that a two-lane service road snakes for miles along its crest. Now, new flood maps being drawn up by the Federal Emergency Management Agency will essentially erase it.

Macy's and its Santa ads are symbolic of the gift-giving spirit. But with this year's supersweet deals, more shoppers have decided to treat themselves instead. "It seemed to me that, here is Black Friday, the kickoff of the holiday gift-giving season, and shoppers were shopping for themselves," Macy's Chief Executive Terry Lundgren said Friday morning. No doubt Mr. Lundgren is happy to accept the gift.

headline: Teen in Oregon Sting to Be Arraigned
summary: A 19-year-old suspect in an alleged plot to detonate explosives in a crowded downtown shopping district here is scheduled to be arraigned Monday in federal court.

headline: Shell Seeks to Sell Texas Gas Fields
summary: Shell Oil Co. has put its South Texas gas fields on the block, and a sale could fetch roughly $1 billion, people familiar with the matter said.

headline: Silver-Haired Deejay Takes a Spin in U.S.
summary: A 69-year-old deejay who goes by the stage name Mamy Rock has spun internationally. She will make her first trip to New York City to perform at the annual fall benefit for the Carter Burden Center for the Aging.

headline: The Key to Success in Cancún Climate Talks
summary: For the U.S. to get what it wants, it needs to stop obsessing about China, and instead focus on China's partners in the Basic bloc: India, South Africa and Brazil.

headline: Enlarging Simple Cameras
summary: For photography buffs, toting around a hefty professional-looking camera has turned into a must-have accessory.

summary: BP said it is selling its stake in Argentina-based oil and gas company Pan American Energy for $7 billion as part of a divestment plan to pay for the Gulf of Mexico spill.

headline: Crop of Small Dairies Hits Market
summary: Decades after most small dairies were forced out of business in New York, a new crop of boutique dairies is springing up in the state to produce fancy cheese, milk and yogurt.

summary: Once-promising plans to build solar-equipment factories in Michigan have slowed or been shelved entirely, dimming prospects for a green-powered boost to an ailing job market.

headline: Employers Still Uncertain On Hiring New Graduates
summary: College graduates might find a better job market this academic year, but many employers are still uncertain if they'll hire at all.

headline: Some U.S. College Students Look to U.K.
summary: As tuition at U.S. colleges increasingly becomes less affordable for many, some high schoolers are looking to the U.K. to meet their needs.

summary: One problem for LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and the Miami Heat has been that the team is passing too much.

headline: Okinawa Vote Could Ease U.S. Base Issue
summary: The conservative incumbent governor of Okinawa won re-election after a hard-fought campaign, providing some hope to Washington and Tokyo for resolving the status of U.S. bases on the southern Japanese island.

headline: Japan Rejects Session on Koreas
summary: Japanese Foreign Minister Seiji Maehara rejected China's proposal to hold emergency talks between North Korea and other nations, saying Pyongyang must first display sincere effort to ease its confrontational posture.

summary: DECLARATIONS  Obama needs to hear a voice from outside the presidential bubble.

summary: The British government has withdrawn support for a proposed barrage across the Severn Estuary, citing the project's high cost and, perhaps surprisingly, its environmental impact.

summary: New derivatives rules could punish firms that pose no systemic risk.

summary: An ample living room in this mid-century modern Phoenix home, makes for a good "party house," says its owner who nicknamed the three-bedroom the "House of the Sun."

summary: Debate has flared about a federal judge panel's order to cut tens of thousands of inmates from California's state prisons.

summary: Jittery markets sidelined a Russian electricity producer's Hong Kong fund-raising hopes even as three other companies began courting investors in a bid to raise a combined $3 billion from the city's stock market.

summary: Why aren't sports stars beating the tax man by demanding ownership stakes as part of their compensation, as executives do?

summary: Just weeks after a Connecticut jury recommended the death penalty in a grizzly triple-murder, some key Democrats say they remain committed to killing that form of punishment.

summary: Traffic to U.S. stores and websites increased 8.7% this Black Friday weekend. The average shopper spent $365.34, up 6.4% from last year.

summary: Google's green-energy executives talk about where the company has invested, and why.

headline: Michael Pettis: How China Can Avoid the Japan Trap
summary: Rebalancing away from exports doesn't need cause stagnation, as long as policy makers stand back.

headline: Did New Rules Worsen Wall Street Pay Situation?
summary: Wall Street pay practices have "worsened" since the financial crisis, says a new study, because firms still tie too much of their compensation to short-term results and have increased salaries to offset curbs on pay.

headline: Chrebet Tackling Life After Football
summary: One of the most popular players in Jets history, Wayne Chrebet has reinvented himself as a financial advisor at Morgan Stanley's Red Bank office.

headline: Fees Fall on '529' Plans; Performance Improves
summary: Among "529" college-savings plans, fees are coming down, and many have eked out more gains than their mutual-fund counterparts in the past five years, according to Morningstar.

headline: Stepping on the Gas
summary: Natural-gas vehicles are taking off in some surprising places, like Pakistan, Argentina and Iran. Some governments support the technology because of tight gasoline-refining capacity and abundant supplies of natural gas.
